Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: STAR (Successfully Transitioning into the Academic Realm) Program at VSU

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Virginia State University (VSU) seeks to enhance the ability of underrepresented minority students to face the challenges of learning science and develop STEM identities to sustain their interest and motivation for pursuit of STEM careers. The proposed intervention, Successfully Transitioning into the Academic Realm (STAR) Program, is designed to facilitate the transition to college-level academics and will build on a previous successful pilot intervention that resulted in an increase in the passing rates for biology majors enrolled in general biology. This project is expected to enhance the ability of underrepresented minority students to face the classroom challenges of learning science, and develop STEM identities which will sustain their interest and motivation to pursue STEM careers.

The STAR program specific objectives are designed to impact cognitive and non-cognitive factors using evidence-based models. This will be accomplished through curricular enhancements to the general biology course and a peer-mentoring, learning-community based approach. The specific goals are to: 1) integrate critical components of BIOL130 Professional Practices in Biology that have been demonstrated to enhance course outcomes into the general biology course for all STEM majors; 2) develop and implement a peer mentoring structure that integrates evidence-based and piloted practices targeting effective academic habits and maximizing student engagement through learning communities; and 3) implement a rigorous evaluation plan to determine program impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While 47% of all US students who enter college intending to major in STEM exit the field, the exit rate for Underrepresented Minorities (URMs) is significantly higher at 65%. Introductory gatekeeper courses remain a major barrier to success with very high rates of failure or withdrawals. While efforts to improve student performance have often focused on academic preparation and tutoring, there are other factors that negatively impact student performance, especially among URMs. These include ineffective pedagogies used for content delivery, difficulties encountered by students in negotiating social and academic cultures in the university setting, diminished academic confidence (i.e., low self-efficacy) and a sense of disconnection or feeling like an imposter within the STEM community (i.e., low STEM identity).

The STAR (Successfully Transitioning into the Academic Realm) Program at Virginia State University (VSU) was designed to enhance the performance of minority STEM majors enrolled in introductory general biology courses by impacting cognitive (grades, concept inventory, persistence, etc.) and non-cognitive (self-efficacy, self-regulation, STEM identity, resilience, etc.) factors. This was partially accomplished through a peer mentoring, learning community based on Supplemental Instruction (SI), a nationally-recognized academic intervention, and Project Knowledge (PK), the evidenced-based highly successful academic intervention developed at VSU. SI utilized collaborative, group study to focus on course-specific learning and study strategies (e.g., time management, note taking, vocabulary, questioning techniques, test preparation, etc.), and was augmented with PK activities designed to address STEM identity and emotional development, and to increase self-regulation while decreasing self-handicapping. Students enrolled in general biology courses attended out-of-class study groups facilitated by highly trained STEM honors students who implemented the principles of SI & PK. From the analysis of our STAR Program data, we found this SI/PK peer-mentoring component of our intervention had a significant impact on students? academic performance. The more STAR program sessions attended, the higher the final score in the general biology course for biology and other STEM majors. High school grade point average (HS-GPA) of first-time college students is often utilized as a predictor of future academic success. Therefore, we analyzed HS-GPA and exam scores of students enrolled in general biology, relative to their STAR session attendance. STAR session attendance significantly impacted the general biology exam scores of both students with low and high entering HS-GPAs. Most notable is that students with low HS-GPA and high STAR session attendance (at least six weeks of the fifteen-week semester) out performed high HS-GPA students with low STAR session attendance. We improved the academic performance of underrepresented minority (URM) STEM majors enrolled in an introductory general biology course. Analysis of the average college semester GPA demonstrated that same trend, indicating STAR session attendance impacted students? performance in all of their fall semester courses. The high impact activities of the STAR Program blended SI/PK peer mentoring paradigm appear to have an effect beyond the general biology course.

VSU?s mission, similar to most HBCUs, is to provide opportunities for historically disenfranchised populations, primarily minority and underprivileged students. Persistence and retention among this population is generally lower in most academic settings. The value added from this STAR program intervention is the specific targeting of a vulnerable population that would otherwise not enter or persist in STEM. We can mitigate K-12 academic deficiencies with the STAR Program intervention and develop, rather than select, students with the potential for academic achievement in STEM fields. Outcomes of this work were disseminated through workshops and presentations at regional and national conferences and presentations at peer institutions and other venues.
